issues.description: The problem statement defines the abstract method messageOnFeed() to return a String, but in the solution Animal.java declares messageOnFeed() to return FeedResponse. This mismatches the specified return type and introduces an extra FeedResponse class not described in the exercise, confusing students about the correct signature.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the solution with the specification by changing Animal.java to declare public abstract String messageOnFeed(), removing or refactoring FeedResponse out of messageOnFeed(), or update the problem statement to consistently require and describe a FeedResponse return type.

issues.description: Within the solution repository, Animal.java declares messageOnFeed() returning FeedResponse, but Goat.java implements messageOnFeed() returning String. This override signature mismatch prevents successful compilation.
issues.suggested_fix: Ensure Goat.java’s messageOnFeed() uses the same return type as declared in Animal.java (either both return FeedResponse or both return String) to satisfy the override contract.

issues.description: The problem statement’s UML specifies that Animal.messageOnFeed() should return a String, but in the solution the method is declared to return a FeedResponse. This introduces a new class name for the same conceptual ‘feed message’ entity and a mismatch in the expected return type, which will confuse students about whether messageOnFeed() should produce a raw String or a FeedResponse object.
issues.suggested_fix: Unify the return type of messageOnFeed() across all artifacts. Either change the solution to have messageOnFeed() return a String (and remove the FeedResponse class), or update the problem statement and template to introduce and require a FeedResponse return type for messageOnFeed().
